title: 111_hr3694
content: The Act may be cited as the "Removing Excess Litigation Involving Energy on Federal Lands Act" or the "RELIEF Act". Congress finds that the United States spends over $1 billion per day importing crude oil, the largest wealth transfer in history. The US has significant oil and natural gas reserves in the outer Continental Shelf. Environmental groups have legally challenged leases in Alaska and the national leasing program, delaying energy resources to the public at a high cost to the economy. The legal challenges delay energy resources reaching the American public, costing the economy. Congress deems expedited judicial review necessary to prevent abuse of the judicial system. Exclusive jurisdiction over causes and claims related to covered energy projects is granted to the United States District Court for the District of Columbia. All causes and claims must be filed within 60 days of the action or decision by a Federal official, or they will be barred. SEC. 5. District Court for the District of Columbia must resolve all proceedings subject to section 3 within 180 days, taking precedence over other matters. Failure to comply results in dismissal with prejudice. SEC. 6. Only the Supreme Court can review judgments from the district court. SEC. 7. Deadline for appeal to the Supreme Court. An interlocutory or final judgment, decree, or order of the district court may be reviewed by no other court except the Supreme Court. Deadline for appeal to the Supreme Court is set at 180 days after the judgment is issued, with all proceedings taking precedence over other matters before the Supreme Court. Limitation on scope of review and relief is also specified. SEC. 8. LIMITATION ON SCOPE OF REVIEW AND RELIEF. In judicial review of Federal actions, administrative findings are presumed correct unless proven otherwise. Prospective relief must be narrowly drawn and minimally intrusive to correct violations. SEC. 9. LEGAL FEES. SEC. 9. LEGAL FEES. Any person filing a petition for judicial review under this Act must pay prevailing parties' fees unless the Court finds their position justified. SEC. 10. EXCLUSION. This Act does not apply to disputes between lease parties. SEC. 11. COVERED ENERGY PROJECT DEFINED. SEC. 11. COVERED ENERGY PROJECT DEFINED. The term "covered energy project" in this Act refers to actions or decisions by Federal officials regarding leasing Federal lands for energy exploration, development, production, processing, or transmission, including actions under such leases.
